>A Department of Homeland Security spokesperson told Reuters that the U.S. decision was in response [to drug trafficking](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/trump-tariffs-canada-trade-fact-check/).

So you're telling me that they are trafficking drugs through a library? That's amazing.

posts.title: United pilot attacked passenger for taking too long in the bathroom, lawsuit alleges | US news
top_comments:
>	Liebb said when he asked why they were being detained, an officer tightened his handcuffs and responded: “This isn’t county or state. We are homeland. You have no rights here.”

What is this 1984 shit?
Every time I take a united flight, I joke about brushing up on street fighting skills, because we all know “fLight club” is real at united.
The pilots would’ve used the lav nearer the flight deck, not the one in the back
I’m shocked SHOCKED that an airline famous for [breaking guitars](https://youtu.be/5YGc4zOqozo) and [dragging a doctor off a plane](https://youtu.be/VrDWY6C1178) would do something so callous.

That sucks but there’s a small part of me that wants to do this whenever someone is in there taking way too long because they’re just scrolling…

Like please bro, I accidentally had some milk and now my ass is gonna explode.

Yeahhh, I think people need to wait and see where this leads. The article is strictly from the plaintiffs perspective because the airline won't comment.

I have a hard time believing a pilot would break a door down to pull a man out who was just using the restroom. There had to be something else going on. 

Like was the guy being belligerent? Was he actually suffering from an issue or was he doing something else in the bathroom? Obviously he's not going to say "yeah I wasn't really going to the bathroom, I was hanging out for 30+ minutes and being a dickhead to the staff." Also the plaintiff doesn't specify when it happened, perhaps the plane was close to landing? As everyone knows you can't be in the bathroom during that. Maybe the pilot/flight attendants were concerned he was lying because he was in there for 30+ minutes.

A pilot isn't going to risk their license/job by attacking a passenger and doing damage to the plane. Something had to be going on.
The pilot did not break the lock. The bathroom door on an airplane can be unlocked very easily from the outside.
Ok but 30 minutes? Cmon.
This headline and story seem doubtful
Was it an off duty pilot that went and did that? As a pilot you never go back during flight to get involved in a passenger issue, especially a potential security one.

posts.title: The Pentagon's DEI purge: Officials describe a scramble to remove and then restore online content
top_comments:
*While the pages of some well-known veterans... are now back up on Pentagon websites, officials warn that many posts tagged for removal in error may be gone forever.*

Sounds familiar:  they're great at razing but not at raising.
A great use of our tax dollars for sure! /s
What are the odds they will quietly remove them again in a few months, hoping people will be distracted by another thing?

These revisionists deemed the Enola Gay, the Tuskegee airmen, and Major General Charles Rogers's Medal of Honor DEI. They are trying to scrub the history of the military and they call themselves patriots and America First. People really should have paid attention to Project 2025 since now, we have to wait until 2026 to change the Congress.
They also took down the web pages concerning the most decorated military unit in US history, the 442nd Regimental Combat Team. An outcry from veterans restored it.
Racist, homophobic assholes.

Why would people that want to overthrow our democracy spend this much time and effort pissing off the military FOR NO TANGIBLE BENEFIT?

Well I suppose if these people were smart they wouldn’t be racist..
Can’t have anyone thinking women, gays, or the blacks materially participated in our military. /s
It's almost like big balls wrote an algorithm that checks everything against a keyword list of things that this admin wants to erase from history.

I know that they're sworn to obedience, and they are being given lawful orders.

But the orders echo the Nazi purges of the past century. They are actions that mirror the policies of our enemies. The nation mobilized against such things, pouring out blood and treasure to stop them. It was one of our proudest moments, and one that serves to define how we see ourselves as a nation.

The Pentagon shouldn't be "scrambling" to obey such orders, however technically lawful they may be. This purge impresses a stain on the honor of our Armed Forces that will never be expunged. I would expect them to be slow-walking every step. Every order should be met by the impenetrable bureaucracy and red tape that military organizations are famous for. Every signature should be obtained only after each word of the orders and plans are inspected in detail, reviewed by committees, stamped, filed, lost, found, encoded with reference numbers, and distributed to each relevant department. If a form must be filled out, pens should be requisitioned for the purpose. When the pens arrive, they should be deemed unsuitable because the ink viscosity doesn't comply with procurement regulations. The rejected shipment should be returned, and a refund from the contracted vendor obtained and accounted before a new requisition is originated. And once pens are obtained, the forms can be filled out in proper triplicate, to be separated and filed in their widespread destinations. 

Un-American orders need not be expedited; they should be completed with "all deliberate speed". Emphasis on "deliberation". If the "Received" stamp is crooked in its little square, the paperwork should be rejected without explanation until a communication is established to convey that the papers need to be re-done, with a proper cross-reference number linking the rejected paperwork with the replacement.

Removing an entry on a website *ought to take MONTHS.*

posts.title: United pilot attacked passenger for taking too long in the bathroom, lawsuit alleges | US news
top_comments:
>	Liebb said when he asked why they were being detained, an officer tightened his handcuffs and responded: “This isn’t county or state. We are homeland. You have no rights here.”

What is this 1984 shit?
Every time I take a united flight, I joke about brushing up on street fighting skills, because we all know “fLight club” is real at united.
The pilots would’ve used the lav nearer the flight deck, not the one in the back
I’m shocked SHOCKED that an airline famous for [breaking guitars](https://youtu.be/5YGc4zOqozo) and [dragging a doctor off a plane](https://youtu.be/VrDWY6C1178) would do something so callous.

That sucks but there’s a small part of me that wants to do this whenever someone is in there taking way too long because they’re just scrolling…

Like please bro, I accidentally had some milk and now my ass is gonna explode.

Yeahhh, I think people need to wait and see where this leads. The article is strictly from the plaintiffs perspective because the airline won't comment.

I have a hard time believing a pilot would break a door down to pull a man out who was just using the restroom. There had to be something else going on. 

Like was the guy being belligerent? Was he actually suffering from an issue or was he doing something else in the bathroom? Obviously he's not going to say "yeah I wasn't really going to the bathroom, I was hanging out for 30+ minutes and being a dickhead to the staff." Also the plaintiff doesn't specify when it happened, perhaps the plane was close to landing? As everyone knows you can't be in the bathroom during that. Maybe the pilot/flight attendants were concerned he was lying because he was in there for 30+ minutes.

A pilot isn't going to risk their license/job by attacking a passenger and doing damage to the plane. Something had to be going on.
The pilot did not break the lock. The bathroom door on an airplane can be unlocked very easily from the outside.
Ok but 30 minutes? Cmon.
This headline and story seem doubtful
Was it an off duty pilot that went and did that? As a pilot you never go back during flight to get involved in a passenger issue, especially a potential security one.
